pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66:1.6: _Pajānāth’āvuso_, literally, “You know, friends.” According to the commentary to  DN-a 2.436: _Tvaṁ pajānāhīti tvaṁ jāna. Sace gaṇhitukāmosi, gaṇhāhīti vuttaṁ hoti_, “_Tvaṁ pajānāhi_: you know. If you wish to take it, please do: this is what is meant.” In other words, it’s up to you to do what you like.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66:2.1.6: The meaning of the last of these three ways of knowing, _so vā āroceti_, is not clear. CPD suggests: “_sa (sā) āroceti_ (?). Perhaps this last form is conformable to sa. _ārocayate_ med. caus. in the meaning: he or she makes inquiries (of others).” However, this does not fit with the parallel usage at [pli-tv-bu-vb-pc29:3.1.6]() where the text says that she tells (_sā vā āroceti_) him, presumably referring to the nun telling the monk. In this case _āroceti_ cannot refer to the monk making inquiries. The commentaries are silent, and I therefore assume that a straightforward meaning is the most likely one. I would suggest, then, that it refers to the group of travelers (i.e. the thieves or one of them) telling the monk directly.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc66:2.1.15: For a discussion of the _yojana_, see Appendix of Technical Terms.
